results.title: The Star
results.creator_credit: Lawrence Pitkethly, Danielle Gardner, BBC, KCET (Television station : Los Angeles, Calif.) and New York Center for Visual History
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “American cinema”.
Greta Garbo, Cary Grant, Dustin Hoffman - these amongst many others are names synonymous with Hollywood. Early on, Hollywood saw that recognisable talent could minimise the financial risks of film production. Critics, film scholars and studio publicists view the stars from many angles, as marketing tools, cultural icons and products of the industry. Joan Crawford is used as a case study.

results.title: The Film school generation
results.creator_credit: Steve Jenkins, BBC, KCET (Television station : Los Angeles, Calif.) and New York Center for Visual History
results.brief_description:
Episode number 9 of Series “American cinema”.
Maverick filmmakers of the 1960’s and 1970’s including Brian DePalma, Martin Scorsese and Steven Spielberg, capitalized on new technology and borrowed from the classical Hollywood and French New Wave as they as they reinvented the American film. The financial and cultural forces that contributed to their success and commercial clout are explored.

results.title: Romantic comedy
results.creator_credit: Molly Ornati, BBC, KCET (Television station : Los Angeles, Calif.) and New York Center for Visual History
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “American cinema”.
Breezy and silly to witty and intelligent, romantic comedies have been around since the 1930’s but the surface humour barely masked issues of gender and sexuality. This program reviews screwball comedies including “It happened one night” and “His girl Friday” and analyses more recent interpretations of the genre by directors like Nora Ephron and James Brooks.

results.title: The Final Academy Documents 1982
results.brief_description: The second video in the ‘Final Academy Documents’ contains William S. Burroughs reading his novel and John Giorno reading his poetry to music recorded at the “Fianl Academy” evening at the Hacienda Club in Manchester in 1982.

results.title: The Flight of the snows
results.creator_credit: Jean-Louis Frund, Donald Duprey, International Cinemedia Centre Ltd and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: The snow goose is a tightly scheduled bird. It winters in the United States, flies 4,000 kilometres to breed and raise a family in the high Arctic, and returns before the frost sets in. This film documents the formation-flying, feeding habits, rearing of young and lifestyle of the great snow goose. Written by Joseph Koenig; music by James Solkin; voice and narration by Bud Knapp.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jean-Louis Frund, Donald Duprey, International Cinemedia Centre Ltd and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: The Studio system
results.creator_credit: Lawrence Pitkethly, BBC, KCET (Television station : Los Angeles, Calif.) and New York Center for Visual History
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “American cinema”.
This program surveys Hollywood’s industrial past during the era of contract players and directors, studio police forces and colourful movie moguls. It also overviews the modern film-making environment with studio heads Michael Eisner, Howard Koch and others. Paramount Pictures, one of the oldest and most successful of the Hollywood studios, serves as a case study.

results.title: The Final academy documents 1962/63
results.brief_description: Contains archival film footage of William S. Burroughs and Brion Gysin, filmed by the late Anthony Balch in 1962-1963. Includes “Ghosts at Number 9” and the classic film “Towers Open Fire”.
results.description: Contains archival film footage of William S. Burroughs and Brion Gysin, filmed by the late Anthony Balch in 1962-1963. Includes “Ghosts at Number 9” and the classic film “Towers Open Fire”.

results.title: Film in the television age
results.creator_credit: Elizabeth Foster, Alain Klarer, BBC, KCET (Television station : Los Angeles, Calif.) and New York Center for Visual History
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series “American cinema”.
Television arrived in American homes just as the Hollywood studio system was collasping. As the new medium took hold, so did a new era in motion picture entertainment. Renown directors, film scholars and actors trace the influence of each medium upon the other; from the live and fresh dramas of the Golden Age of Television and the growth of Hollywood spectacles to the modern day megalithic entertainment industry.

results.title: The Film of the Royal Ballet
results.creator_credit: Paul Czinner, Poetic Films and Royal Opera House Covent Garden
results.brief_description: Starring Margot Fonteyn, the great Prima Ballerina, in the principal female roles and Michael Somes in the lead male roles, this film showcases three of ballets’ most moving performances. Three tragic tales of doomed love filmed during performances of the Corps De Ballet of the Royal Opera House. Director of Ballet is Dame Ninette De Valois. Music is performed by the Covent Garden Orchestra. The first is Piotr Tchaikovsky’s brilliant “Swan Lake, Act II” which depicts the powerful meeting of the hunter, Prince Siegfried, and the prey, a graceful swan who transforms into a beautiful girl. The second performance is of Igor Stravinsky’s “The firebird”, the story of a travelling prince who captures a fantastical firebird who bargains her way to freedom by giving him one of her magic feathers. The third performance is of Hans Werner Henze’s “Ondine”, the story of Palemon, who is torn between his love of Berta and a water-sprite, Ondine.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Paul Czinner, Poetic Films and Royal Opera House Covent Garden
results.description: Starring Margot Fonteyn, the great Prima Ballerina, in the principal female roles and Michael Somes in the lead male roles, this film showcases three of ballets’ most moving performances. Three tragic tales of doomed love filmed during performances of the Corps De Ballet of the Royal Opera House. Director of Ballet is Dame Ninette De Valois. Music is performed by the Covent Garden Orchestra. The first is Piotr Tchaikovsky’s brilliant “Swan Lake, Act II” which depicts the powerful meeting of the hunter, Prince Siegfried, and the prey, a graceful swan who transforms into a beautiful girl. The second performance is of Igor Stravinsky’s “The firebird”, the story of a travelling prince who captures a fantastical firebird who bargains her way to freedom by giving him one of her magic feathers. The third performance is of Hans Werner Henze’s “Ondine”, the story of Palemon, who is torn between his love of Berta and a water-sprite, Ondine.
description_for_label: Starring Margot Fonteyn, the great Prima Ballerina, in the principal female roles and Michael Somes in the lead male roles, this film showcases three of ballets’ most moving performances. Three tragic tales of doomed love filmed during performances of the Corps De Ballet of the Royal Opera House. Director of Ballet is Dame Ninette De Valois. Music is performed by the Covent Garden Orchestra. The first is Piotr Tchaikovsky’s brilliant “Swan Lake, Act II” which depicts the powerful meeting of the hunter, Prince Siegfried, and the prey, a graceful swan who transforms into a beautiful girl. The second performance is of Igor Stravinsky’s “The firebird”, the story of a travelling prince who captures a fantastical firebird who bargains her way to freedom by giving him one of her magic feathers. The third performance is of Hans Werner Henze’s “Ondine”, the story of Palemon, who is torn between his love of Berta and a water-sprite, Ondine.
